causes: Rising nationalism among Slavic populations in the Balkans
Russian desire to expand influence over the Balkans and the Ottoman Empire’s weakening state
Ottoman inability to suppress uprisings in its Balkan territories
Russia’s ambition to gain access to the warm-water ports of the Black Sea
events_leading_up_to_war: Russian support for Slavic revolts in the Balkans, especially Bulgaria
Ottoman brutal suppression of uprisings, including the Bulgarian Massacre of 1876
Russia declares war on the Ottoman Empire in April 1877, citing the protection of Orthodox Christians in the Balkans as a pretext

result.treaty: Treaty of San Stefano (1878), later modified by the Congress of Berlin (1878)
territorial_changes: Ottoman Empire loses large territories in the Balkans (including parts of Romania, Bulgaria, and Serbia)
Russia gains significant territorial concessions in the Caucasus and Eastern Anatolia
Bulgaria is created as a principality under Russian influence (later reduced in size by the Congress of Berlin)

Russian_Empire.artillery: Advanced artillery, including heavy siege guns

Ottoman_Empire.naval_power: Outnumbered by the Russian fleet in the Black Sea
Ottoman_Empire.artillery: Outdated artillery compared to Russian forces

Ottoman_Empire.dead: Approximately 200,000 (including civilian casualties from the Balkan uprisings)

major_battles.name: Battle of Plevna
major_battles.description: A protracted siege where Russian and Romanian forces laid siege to Ottoman defensive positions, ultimately breaking through after several months.

major_battles.name: Battle of Shipka Pass
major_battles.description: One of the key victories of Russian and Bulgarian forces, where Russian and Bulgarian troops held off a large Ottoman force in a mountain pass.

major_battles.name: Siege of Kars
major_battles.description: The Russian Army captured the strategically vital fortress of Kars after a prolonged siege, marking the final Russian victory in the Caucasus.

terms: Russia gains control of territories in the Caucasus, Romania, and Bulgaria
Ottoman Empire cedes large parts of its territory, including Kars, Batumi, and Bessarabia
Creation of the Bulgarian Principality, a Russian client state
impact: Russia becomes the dominant power in the Balkans
Ottoman Empire’s territorial losses further weaken it, contributing to the empire’s gradual decline
The creation of Bulgaria as a major regional power

terms: The Treaty of San Stefano is revised to reduce Bulgaria’s size, preventing a large Russian satellite in the Balkans
Serbia, Montenegro, and Romania gain recognition of independence
Ottoman Empire retains nominal control over much of the Balkans, though it remains weakened
impact: The Congress of Berlin is seen as a diplomatic setback for Russia
The war contributes to the long-term instability in the Balkans, leading to future conflicts in the 20th century

long_term_effects: Emerging nationalist movements in the Balkans gain momentum, leading to the eventual disintegration of the Ottoman Empire
Russia’s influence in the region remains a key factor in the dynamics of Eastern European politics until World War I

economic: Significant financial strain on the Ottoman Empire, contributing to its declining economic power
Increased Russian military expenditure and expansion
political: Further erosion of Ottoman power, particularly in the Balkans and Caucasus
Russia’s continued dominance in Eastern Europe, influencing the Great Powers for decades
social: Nationalism increases in the Balkans, leading to the rise of new nation-states
Ottoman Empire struggles to maintain control over its diverse populations
